talk.start.para: —The government has to get serious about food labelling. The government must listen to the community on this issue. Deregulation of food labelling is not good for the industry and it is not acceptable to consumers. It is hard to imagine an issue more serious in our local community than those issues that involve our basic necessities. Food of course is one of life's basic requirements. There is no-one in our community who is unaffected where food is concerned. In Australia we have become accustomed to high quality food products, both fresh and processed. We are entitled to this expectation for good reason. We have tighter controls and regulations on food products than most other countries.

speech.para: The community expectation on the supply and marketing of quality food demands that issues of value and health are also addressed. The government has a major role to play in relation to ensuring the community has access to a food supply that is safe to eat, free of unhealthy herbicides and pesticides and that meets the nutritional expectations of the community. We must also ensure that consumers are given the capacity to evaluate food value as against food prices to ensure that the community has access to food that is value for money.

Increasingly, many consumers are also demanding that foods be produced in ways that are ethically sound and environmentally sustainable. Meeting the varying demands of consumers in a free market economy where primary producers must also compete against imported foodstuffs and maximise exports of local food products is clearly the challenge. While regulation is obviously the only path to take on public health and safety issues like pesticides and herbicides, it is unrealistic to strictly regulate on matters relating to nutritional expectation and value for money.

The important issue at hand here is that consumers are given the information they need to make decisions on the criteria they feel are important in their choice of food. The solution is food labelling. Food labelling is the consumers' only realistic method of determining what the food is and whether one product differs greatly in terms of expectation of ingredients, manufacturing processes or nutritional outcomes. There should be no debate that information is a vital part of the freedoms associated with a healthy market economy. Without informed choice consumers are left to the peril of marketing, deception or ambiguity. The government's plans to deregulate food labelling will abandon the consumer and the confidence we have in our present system.

Labor has a history of taking food labelling very seriously. When in government we tackled the difficult issues of food labelling, in particular, the matter of country of origin labelling and the protection of the `Product of Australia' tag, unlike the current government, who shed crocodile tears when in opposition on this issue but when in government watered down the level of Australian goods required to bear the label `Made in Australia'. This government have never taken food labelling seriously. They do not understand this issue from the point of view of the consumer.

Members opposite should understand that the Australian consumer today is hungry for information on food. When my family and I are shopping, I notice that many shoppers, like us, are now stopping before they put food into the trolley. They are reading the labels. People want to know the nutritional content, the country of origin, the ingredients and any other facts they can find out about the products before they make a purchase. Of course they also take some things for granted—like the fact that jam contains fruit—and they should be entitled to do so. These things are the matters usually dealt with by food labelling regulations.

One issue of growing concern for consumers is the use of genetically modified organisms in the manufacture of food products. People have a wide range of concerns about the use of GMOs in food—from the ethical and spiritual concerns through to the nutritional, taste and health aspects of genetically altered food. Concerns with GMOs often underlie a deep and fundamental concern about gene technology and the application of this technology in the commercial world. We all live in a technological age where we sometimes quite rightly fear that science can disregard the human perspective. Morally or ethically, human discovery does not always lead to human progress. The gene industry is one that some people would never wish to sponsor and as such would purchase their food free of such technology. This can only be achieved when they have reasonable access to that information through food labelling.

This government is very loud when talking about mutual obligation and freedom of choice in relation to many matters, as we have heard recently. So it should be incumbent on this government to offer the same freedoms of choice to consumers through legislation and proper food labelling. There is a lot of information about this subject that people need to know. As that information becomes available, attitudes to GMOs may well change. While concerns exist and for varying reasons the community may wish to avoid genetically altered food, food labelling must identify any foods where GMOs are used.

This will not happen under this government because it cannot get it right on food labelling. The government has not taken seriously the fact that there is near zero compliance of the requirement for testing and approval of genetically modified food products. There is little to no chance that consumers or retailers will have identified all the products with genetically modified organisms by the 13 May deadline. While this places retailers in an unenviable position, for consumers it will mean that they are no closer to finding out the truth on what they are buying or what they are eating—a situation that may please the government, which, after all, voted against the labelling of genetically modified foods late last year.

Food labelling is about much more than just genetically modified organisms. Food labelling is an issue for every product we purchase. Food labelling allows consumers the confidence to purchase products of a particular description and to know that that product falls within the community expectation of ingredients and nutritional requirements. The government's current plans to deregulate food labelling will pull the rug out from under consumers' feet. Nearing Easter it is timely to consider the government's deregulation of food labelling and its impact.

Will the coalition hop from house to house this Easter telling kids and their parents that the chocolate Easter eggs they are eating may contain no chocolate at all? Or will the government tell consumers that it will remove the requirement for jam to contain at least 40 per cent fruit? And what of the great Australian meat pie? An Aussie icon of such magnitude, it is surprising that it did not get a run in John Howard's preamble. Even guidelines for the meat pie will be thrown out the window under this government's recommendations.

Food labelling regulations are put in place to assist the consumer. Consumers only get a fair deal when they can go to the supermarket and compare apples with apples and jams with jams. The ability of manufacturers to produce, for example, jams of inferior fruit quality without labelling as such will lead to many consumers purchasing products that are of a reduced value for money. Consumers are owed better than this from this government or any government. They work too hard and earn too little to throw money away at the supermarket. Only regulated food labelling will assist the consumer in making informed comparisons at the point of purchase.

Food labelling is also a genuine health issue. When you are shopping for yourself and your family, you want to know that a certain product is made from the ingredients that you expect. With deregulated food labelling, the nutritional value of food can be seriously diminished without consumers being aware of this. This is of genuine concern to many. Without regulated food labelling, public nutrition can be played off against industry expedience. With food labelling deregulation what is removed are the minimum standards of ingredients that are usually healthier, fresher and generally better for us. Of course, they are usually more expensive. Therefore, a manufacturer of jams can reduce the amount of fruit in a jam jar but they can still call it jam. They will reduce their costs and still compete against other jam manufacturers.

Where will this eventually lead us? All the jam manufacturers will be forced to reduce their fruit content to compete. The eventual loser is the consumer. As a parent, I want to know that the jam I buy for my family contains a minimum of fruit, that a meat pie contains a minimum of meat and that the integrity of other food products is also maintained. Without that integrity we cannot properly assess the balance of diets of our families or ourselves. That, quite frankly, is just not good enough.

Further, I am concerned that Australia's international reputation as a manufacturer of quality foods will be diminished by the falling standards of domestic production. It is widely acknowledged that Australia's food exporters succeed by not only competing by price alone but also providing the world with superior quality foods. The deregulation of food labelling will only serve to reduce this reputation on primary products.

The impact of the export on processed foods could be far more serious. Export opportunities for value added products lie very much in the top end of the market. Through tourism and other mediums, the global community will develop a particular belief in the quality of Australian food—qualities that must be maintained and, if anything, increased if locally manufactured goods are to compete in overseas markets. For all these reasons, the government needs to get serious about food labelling. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am sure that the member for Oxley was going to finish by saying that he particularly encouraged people to take account of food labelling of jam in the future, so I will add that for him. I, too, am very concerned about the fruit content in jam. It has been of great concern to me for a long time. I am glad that the member for Oxley is speaking up in this House on behalf of all of those of us who have a great concern about the fruit content of our jams.

speech.para: Globalisation is challenging our traditional ideas of economic policy as capital becomes more diffuse and economic borders more porous. Technological change is reducing the power and capacity of governments to control economies free from outside influence. The challenge for government is to create the architecture which will enable Australia to successfully compete for investment in an era where capital will become even more mobile.

Australia needs to embrace a business taxation framework which is incentive based, as free as possible from economic distortions and transparent. Transparency in business and government will be the new buzz word as we enter the next millennium. The coalition government is pioneering transparency practices both domestically and abroad. Domestically, the charter of budget honesty requires a government to report all of its liabilities, whether the budget is going into deficit and, if so, how it will get out of deficit, and independent costings of election promises. Internationally, the coalition government has released a transparency report which will lend itself to superior regional economic surveillance and will be the model used by the International Monetary Fund to determine whether it can be applied to other countries around the world.

Transparency arrangements have the advantage of demonstrating to market participants that we have confidence in our economy and financial infrastructure. This is a necessary measure if we want to remain a competitive destination for international capital. But as the international marketplace moves to follow Australia's lead in transparency arrangements, there is an urgency to complete reforms to our taxation system to maximise investment opportunities. The last peg in the government's tax reform strategy is to improve the business taxation system and move towards a lower, more uniform and efficient company tax rate with less distortionary mechanisms.

The most visible feature of a country's business tax system is its company tax rate. Slashing the company tax rate from 36 per cent to 30 per cent would earn Australia a reputation as an attractive and efficient place to invest and do business. The benefits would be shared by all Australians through an inevitable boost in economic growth and job creation.

talk.start.para: —The pensioners will be screaming.
—It will be of benefit to all Australians, I say to the member for Grayndler—in his new lilac shirt which he asked me to comment on in my speech today; looking particularly spivvy.
—I rise on a point of order. I would ask that the member for Sturt withdraw—
—The reference to the lilac shirt?
—The reference to the shirt is entirely appropriate, but the reference to a group of people which seems to dominate his party—that is, spivs—I find offensive.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. If the honourable member has taken offence to certain words, I would ask the honourable member for Sturt to withdraw.

—Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. Because I do not want to lose any more time, I am happy to withdraw. Considering a country's corporate tax rate in isolation is adopting a narrow and limited approach. The country with the lowest rate of company tax will not always be the most attractive place to invest. Potential investors consider other peripheral factors, such as liability for other taxes like payroll tax, the skills and flexibility of the labour market and industrial relations regulations. Other considerations include the manner in which corporate taxes are administered. Some countries adopt a dual income tax approach in which they apply a low rate of tax to the earnings of companies but tax the income more heavily in the hands of domestic shareholders. Other countries, such as Germany, have a split rate system, applying different rates to both distributed and undistributed income.

speech.para: Reducing Australia's corporate tax rate from 36 per cent is only half the challenge. The invisibility of economic distortions and the costs of compliance for businesses and government through the Australian Taxation Office are compelling arguments for reforming the corporate tax system beyond a reduction in the rate. Some of these distortions are caused by concessional treatment of corporate tax liabilities. One such concession is accelerated depreciation of an asset, which allows companies to depreciate an asset for tax purposes faster than it depreciates commercially. Australia provides more generous depreciation allowances compared to most other countries for assets with longer economic lives. This tends to arise because of the broadbanding approach to fixing the rates as well as the underlying concessional treatment that is built into the rates.

Australia's mining, manufacturing and agricultural industries are all heavy beneficiaries of the present system. The capital intensive nature of mining, particularly in the early stages of a project, means that the concessional treatment of accelerated depreciation reduces the cost burden in the embryonic stages of a development. This has the effect of substantially improving returns from the investment over the long term. It is effectively an industry subsidy. Clearly, the government must be cognisant of the impact that the removal of this concession might have on existing industries.

However, it is difficult to ignore the advantages of a lower and more uniform application of corporate tax. A reduction of company tax rates would encourage the expansion of less capital intensive industries, particularly industries which are exporting services. Reforms to the corporate tax rate would foster a broader range of foreign investment which would extend beyond mining and manufacturing and make many of our domestic industries more internationally competitive. Removing or reducing accelerated depreciation as a concession would also remove distortions. Although concessions have a distortionary effect on the economy, well-targeted concessions can enjoy a place in the tax system. But if you have less distortions in the tax system then everyone enjoys the benefits.

Economic efficiency is best achieved if consumption patterns are determined by the true cost of production and not by tax considerations. The concessional treatment of accelerated depreciation works against that principle. The current tax system fails to achieve adequate efficiency because producer behaviour is distorted as production favours low-taxed goods and services. The consequent price distortions affect investment decisions, innovation and product development.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—I am delighted the member for Werriwa was pleased with my point in my speech, because I have some regard for his economic credentials and the work that he has done since the last election. I am sorry that his economic credentials are not so well recognised by other members of the Labor Party—like the member for Grayndler, who I understand is not quite as supportive of the member for Werriwa as are members on this side of the House.

speech.para: The objective of responsible tax policy should be to minimise the impact of taxes on production and consumption decisions. There must be a cogent argument to allow dis tortionary measures in a tax system. Supporters of the status quo argue that any significant changes to the present system will expose established capital intensive industries and may drive away existing investors who were initially drawn to our present system. Others argue that setting the corporate tax rate as low as 30 per cent would accelerate the shift of pay-as-you-earn taxpayers into company structures to minimise personal taxation liability.

This recycled argument has no contemporary relevance. In the modern global economy, the mobility of capital requires countries to have an internationally competitive corporate tax system if they want to capture their share of that capital. To continue with a corporate tax system which does not take sufficient account of international factors would be to risk a declining revenue base, expiring levels of foreign investment and a poorer competitive position for Australian enterprises and Australian based multinationals. If Australia is to remain competitive, we need to lower the company tax rate to 30 per cent and reduce distortionary measures in the tax system.

It is difficult to project the impact of removing concessions on market behaviour and market driven resource allocation. Based on Treasury projections, lowering the corporate tax rate to 30 per cent would cost approximately $4½ billion in transition costs by 2003-04 and would come at an annual cost to the Commonwealth budget of around $2.2 billion. Removing the concessional treatment of accelerated depreciation would recoup $2.4 billion. This would have the twofold advantage of making the exercise revenue neutral while removing some of the distortions in the current business tax system. Such a proposal deserves serious consideration by government and industry. The Minerals Council of Australia has already indicated that it could `possibly' embrace supporting the removal or modification of accelerated depreciation.

We should avoid the pitfall of borrowing a corporate tax system from another country and grafting it onto our own tax and legislative frameworks. Australia should be looking to learn from the experiences of other count ries rather than looking for an off-the-shelf panacea. The international race to improve the competitiveness of national corporate tax systems illustrates the urgency for Australia to keep ahead of our competitors. The faster we achieve reform, the faster we will make progress as a country. At the moment, the government's reform process is being delayed by some sections of the Senate which want to prolong the personal income tax reform debate. That debate is finished: the Australian electorate voted in favour of the government's tax reform package at the last election. The Senate has an obligation to all Australians to pass tax reform. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The history of cross-media laws in this parliament is well known. They were devised by Paul Keating during his time as Treasurer and then vigorously defended during his time as Prime Minister. These laws stand in the way of the Packer group acquiring the Fairfax newspapers. For the Packer family, this is an article of faith. As Kerry Packer himself said in October 1991:

speech.para: For 50 years of my life Fairfax has been in competition to me and my family. The idea that I can end up buying it amuses me.

What for Mr Packer is a matter of family redemption and personal amusement has been seen by this parliament as sound competition policy. No matter how much information can be dispersed on the Internet, no matter how prolific the information superhighway may become, competition policy will still matter.

The information age, while changing the format of economic regulation, is not an invitation for laissez faire, nor is it an invitation for oligopoly markets. This country already has a relatively high concentration of media ownership across the established technologies of print, radio and television. Obviously, the major players want to extend their ownership and control into emerging media technologies. Competition policy needs to guard against this scenario. It is not desirable for the princes of print and the queens of the screen in Australia to now become moguls of multimedia and kings of content. Rather than abolishing the cross-media laws, it is time to update their effectiveness.

I have long been an advocate of a policy of vertical separation for the new media technologies—that is, content provision, multimedia delivery and cable ownership. An access regime should be established for media content, just as the Hilmer reforms have entrenched open access rules for service carrying public infrastructure in Australia. Within this framework, the print media would be classified as part of content provision. The Packer organisation would still need to make a choice: does it want to be a provider of television and other multimedia services or a newspaper owner? The integrity and intent of the cross-media laws would then be preserved.

I note that Mr Packer is now advocating the abolition of both the cross-media laws and foreign ownership restrictions in the media. This is far from amusing, especially given this is the same Mr Packer who just a few years ago—indeed, on 16 February 1995—said:
Nowhere in the world, and I mean nowhere . . . is there not some control over media assets by nationals.
This was the same Mr Packer who, on 18 November 1996, said:

Australian media companies talk an Australian language and their prime loyalty both in a business sense and as corporate citizens is to Australia. What we are now talking about is the preservation of national identity and pride.

It is always surprising when a strident economic nationalist becomes a born-again internationalist. I suspect that Mr Packer's conversion is not so much to do with public policy as with self-interest. Mr Packer has justified this change in position by arguing:
I think the world changes and you can't just sit there in isolation.

It is true that the world does constantly change, but some things in it remain remarkably constant. Take, for instance, the Packer organisation's approach to media policy. Paul Barry's biography of Mr Packer offers a remarkable account of single-minded purpose and consistency across three generations. From Robert Clyde Packer's crusade against Jack Lang, to Frank Packer's personal em brace of Menzies and Askin, to Kerry Packer's endorsement of the current Prime Minister, this has been a Liberal leaning outfit. All three generations have been willing to use their media power for, in the words of Paul Barry, `all sorts of crusades and vendettas and to ride their own personal hobbyhorses'.

This takes me back to Paul Keating, the latest and most spectacular victim of a Packer vendetta. Mr Keating is now paying a public price for standing up to the Packer organisation and blocking its ambition to take over Fairfax. No-one in this parliament, least of all those who truly value the principles of parliamentary independence, should support this campaign. The 60 Minutes allegations are both misleading and malicious. I offer three instances. First, 60 Minutes broadcast that Mr Constantinidis took $100,000 away from the piggery, yet 60 Minutes had in its possession documents which showed that this amount was substantially higher. Mr Keating has subsequently shown it to be $9.1 million. Second, 60 Minutes knowingly failed to report that its star witness, Mr Tony Norman, has been on Mr Constantinidis's payroll. Third, the Commonwealth Bank has totally rejected the 60 Minutes allegations. It has been willing to open its books to full public scrutiny to prove this point.

The parliamentary Liberal Party may think it clever, even amusing, to support these allegations. The Prime Minister at one time thought it clever to have his friend Michael Baume drag these matters through the Senate. Perhaps he now finds it amusing to direct the Attorney-General to go through the charade of an inquiry. There is, of course, nothing to inquire into. Paul Keating has not been a member of this House for three years. His private business affairs deserve no greater scrutiny than any other Australian citizen.

This matter should sound warning bells for all members in this place but for a very different reason to that put by 60 Minutes. The Packer organisation is trying to send a message to anyone who stands in the way of its ambitions for Fairfax. If anyone takes the same stance as Paul Keating, they will end up being subject to the same treatment. This is the standard Packer treatment—the media politics of intimidation and vendettas. Some politicians are more likely to buckle under to this type of treatment than others. This is the reason why the Howard government has had the cross-media rules under a permanent state of review since March 1996. The health of democracy, however, is damaged if any one citizen has the power to intimidate an elected government. Caving into those demands can only worsen the situation.

Politics is full of ironies. Often it follows the dictum that my enemy's enemy is my friend. This can be seen by the way in which Brian Toohey—the contrarian journalist who first peddled the notorious `Goanna' allegations against Mr Packer—is now cheering on the Packer allegations against Mr Keating. Mr Toohey is more interested in settling old scores than reporting the facts. Toohey has a hateful obsession of Indonesia, and this has coloured his reporting of the recent controversies concerning the two former Labor prime ministers Mr Keating and Mr Whitlam. In fact, Keating's letter published in today's Financial Review exposes Toohey as a serial liar. This is a judgment supported by the experience of the Whitlam government, given Mr Toohey's actions in stealing sensitive defence documents from the defence minister's office.

This parliament should reject the Packer and Toohey allegations against Keating. It should also reject Toohey's rewriting of the Whitlam government's record in foreign policy. As Paul Keating made clear in his press release yesterday, it is time to seriously examine the question of journalistic ethics and professionalism, especially when they are so hopelessly abused by programs like 60 Minutes. Most of all, we should reject any weakening of the cross-media principles to which this parliament has subscribed for more than a decade. To weaken those principles is to weaken the health of parliamentary democracy itself. None of us at any time under any circumstances should ever cave in to intimidation.

talk.start.para: —Today I want to highlight in this House a few re gional issues which have evolved over the last 20 years or so. If you were to formulate a checklist of the things that were most important to regional Australians, it would be that their health services be of a reasonably equivalent standard to metropolitan Australia; that their education be of a reasonable quality, standard and cost, as it is for metropolitan families; that their communications be of a reasonably convenient standard to enable them to operate their businesses and to progress the investment that is required to maintain our communities; and that the general investment climate in regional Australia be strong enough to generate as much employment as is possible. Petrol prices should also be reasonably equivalent.

speech.para: For the record, it is worth looking at what has happened over the last 10 to 20 years. I will mention one example to show the very clear difference between regional Australia and metropolitan Australia. Everybody is familiar with SBS. Many people in this place would know that it costs about $100 million per annum of taxpayers' subsidy to run the SBS. Many regional Australians do not have access to SBS. Those that do are offered it on the basis—regretfully from this government but also from the previous government—that they pay for it themselves. There is no subsidy whatsoever. That is a glaring inequity. Metropolitan Australians can access SBS at no cost, but regional Australians must pay for it themselves. It would be far fairer if SBS were funded on a similar per capita basis. Perhaps it could even be capitalised out, considering that it has been subsidised for 20 years. There should at least be some equity between rural Australians and metropolitan Australians.
I want to briefly touch on health. If you look at the Medicare payments per capita per annum per electorate—

talk.start.para: —In regional Australia?

—In regional Australia. The figures that I have are for 1993-94. I am sure there are later figures, but I have not been able to lay my hand on them yet. In 1993-94 the electorate of Kalgoorlie, the largest electorate in the world, had a per capita costing of $137 per head. If you look at the electorate of Sydney, it was $407 per head. Therefore, taxpayers' dollars in the electorate of Sydney were accessed at almost three times the rate of that in the electorate of Kalgoorlie, an inequity that regional Australia would not find acceptable.

speech.para: In its defence, this government has introduced a number of initiatives—for example, higher rural and remote centres of excellence. We have tried to train the professionals in a regionally appropriate way. There have been some initiatives in the GP area. There has been a range of initiatives, but there is this bottom line figure that we cannot avoid. Drawings on the Medicare services are at least 2½ to three times greater in metropolitan Sydney than in the remote areas of Australia. We really need to address that issue.

Touching on education, everybody knows that, if you are a regional Australian, you will have far less opportunity to go to university. Also, you will have significantly less opportunity to acquire the most competitive secondary education—and that, of course, has implications as to whether or not you will be able to access a university education. A lot of work is going into that area and many things are being tried, but that is the fundamental situation.

These things come down to cost. The government has, in the youth allowance, extended the rent subsidy in certain cases which has made it more generous than it was. But I believe the basic issue is that the billions of dollars which are available in those metropolitan facilities are not available to the smaller group of Australians, those millions who live outside the main cities of this country.

Currently, at a time when education and opportunities for the future through education have never been more important, and at a time in regional Australia where change is occurring at a more rapid rate, access to education is inequitable. In fact, I would suggest that greater change, much greater fundamental restructuring, is occurring in regional Australia than in the cities. So there is this issue in terms of education.

A matter of great grievance in regional Australia is that of petrol price. It is an age- old problem. From memory, we have been wrestling with this issue for at least 20 years. The greatest complaint that I used to get from regional retailers was, `We can't buy it wholesale for what the retailers in the city can sell it.' Clearly there is something wrong with a system that allows that to happen. Once again this government has acted, as the previous government endeavoured to, to do some things about this issue. Nevertheless, in dealing with these major oil companies, I think everybody understands that it is not easy to overcome this problem.

So generally there exists this fundamental issue about getting some equity in city and country fuel prices. I have already referred to the issue of the oil code that the government is still trying to negotiate. There is the matter that the price charged at the terminal should be reasonably equivalent or at least as close as possible for everyone, no matter who you are. There are those sorts of issues in which the ACCC takes an interest, and I think it needs to take a greater interest in the issue of accessing supplies at a terminal at a fair dinkum price, no matter how big you are.

You can imagine the concern attaching to this issue. For example, there is a Woolworths in Port Pirie; the people of that town certainly enjoy the opportunity to access cheaper fuel that that store brings with the bigger companies having to match its price. But a small community 20 kilometres away is pretty indignant that it cannot have fuel prices at least 8c to 12c cheaper, similar to its neighbour just down the road. So, for regional people, there are some issues of equity.

Last Friday I participated in an absolutely brilliant ceremony: the opening of the expansion at Roxby Downs or Olympic Dam by the Prime Minister. That expansion was an exercise worth nearly $2 billion. At that opening I had the pleasure of meeting one Norman Foster, a former Labor man who, with great courage, crossed the floor in June 1982 to allow this project to proceed.

There was a lot of banter on the day and it was all in good fun and occurred with good humour. But these are serious issues when relying on an upper house and the vote of one man to allow a $3 billion to $4 billion project to go ahead, with $24 million of royalties currently going to the state government, let alone all the other activity such as employment and a population of 4,000 people. That project would not have occurred but for the courage of one man. Perhaps that puts too much on Norman Foster. But I think it really does show the weaknesses in our system of government where upper houses operate. I am grateful to Norman Foster for crossing the floor and enabling this project to proceed, and for the opportunities it has brought to the people in my electorate. But I think we ignore the excess use of power by our upper houses at our own peril.

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Grey made a couple of comments to which I would respond. I think the member should realise that SBS began because of our multicultural society, for which we were given the opportunity to have a television station which related to a whole variety of cultures, and it has been pushing out into the regions from there. I do not disagree with the honourable member for Grey in his sentiment that perhaps we need more of our migrants to locate themselves in Australia's regional areas. I support him, if that is what his comments were getting at. Similarly, in Tasmania, we need to look at our population base and perhaps expand it.

speech.para: The honourable member also looked at health. Let me tell him that it is his government that is tearing the heart out of health in Tasmania. It is his government that has poured the millions, or the $1.3 billion, into private health insurance at the expense of the public hospital system in this country, especially in Tasmania. As we grapple with trying to keep our hospital system going in Tasmania, the honourable member might like to take up in his party room the issue of getting a bit more money back into the public health system and the public hospital system. That would certainly help my people, the people in the regional districts of Tasmania, and in the region of Tasmania as a whole.

This government's indifference to the needs and aspirations not only of my electorate in Tasmania but the state of Tasmania and its people is a well established fact. In just three short years, the Prime Minister of this country has managed to disappoint and alienate just about everybody in Tasmania, and I think he has done the same in New South Wales. If he wants evidence of that, I am more than happy to provide it to him. Take, for example, a letter I received from a group of people calling themselves the `Disillusioned Voters'. This group of 10 or so people has written to me expressing their deep concern about the direction of a government that ignores the welfare of its battlers, people who are struggling to make a go of their lives on pensions, unemployment benefits and low wages. That letter—and I quote verbatim—states in part:

You the Government won't get us off the dole but the system won't pay us a decent wage to live on and allow us to work. Why do you the politicians allow this to go on? You are all out of control and being blatantly unfair to the lower classes of people in this country. Why are there lower classes? You the politicians make them with your laws for the rich and none for the struggling.

The sense of powerlessness evident in the letter from `Disillusioned Voters' contrasts markedly with the Prime Minister's draft preamble, a clause from which asserts that Australians are `free to release themselves as individuals and free to pursue their hopes and ideals'. I do not think `Disillusioned Voters' feel free to assert themselves as individuals nor do they feel free to pursue their hopes and ideals when, seemingly, every policy that this government has introduced marginalises, victimises and penalises them. In their letter they remind us that young Australians are becoming desperate and that their desperation will not abate until they have a reason, a purpose, a job—something for them to hang onto, something to have, something to do.

In Tasmania, a state which already has 10 per cent plus unemployment, it has been estimated that the introduction of Mr Howard's GST will cost at least 1,000 jobs. With average weekly earnings below the national average, it will bite a bit deeper into the pockets of most Tasmanians than it will for many other Australians. Yet the Prime Minister has ruled out any additional compensation for Tasmania or any compensation for the regions. I am pleased that the honourable member for Mallee is here because he is a man of the regions. He should stand up for the regions, especially in the tax debate that is going on at the moment. He should take a strong position in his party room.

Although the Prime Minister ruled out any additional compensation for Tasmania after the last election, he knows that this government owes the Tasmanian people some money from many years ago, and I am sure that will come back onto the agenda. Confronted with these facts, is it any wonder then that the `Disillusioned Voters' in their letter to me ask:

Why are you politicians hell-bent on making our lives hard just because we live in this state? Will you not be satisfied till everyone in this state gets poorer and more families break up and then crime increases? Is it Mr Howard's policy to keep people down and out?

I think most of us on our side would say, yes, that is his policy position and that is probably what he has nailed his colours to. One can only reply in the affirmative, for this government practises the politics of exclusion rather than inclusion. It does not govern for all of us; it governs for some of us. It most certainly does not govern for the `Disillusioned Voters' of my electorate. These people are asking what they have done to deserve John Howard. They can see the extent to which this government panders to the big end of town, especially to the big companies, who are more concerned with tax minimisation than with the plight of rural people living on income support of $140 a week. In their words:
The companies that are making all the profits are giving nothing back to the people who work in the sweatshops and the country, yet they continue to make profits at the poor people's expense. Why?
The letter concludes with this comment:
Stop giving the rich the tax breaks, as all they are doing is privatising everything and creating unemployment and many of our services are suffering due to this.

Of course they are. I just spoke about the health budget in Tasmania—which you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be very familiar with—having its heart torn out with each agreement that is signed as they cut back, cut back and cut back, especially the services in the outlying areas. I am sure the member for Mallee, who is still in the House listening to my speech—I thank him for that—is going to take something from this as a regional member. I certainly hope he does take it up strongly with his government.

This letter is a cry from the bush. It is a demand that the government abandon its plans to sell off the remains of Telstra. It is a demand for a taxation system that is fair and equitable to all Australians. It is a demand for recognition for ordinary people—for ordinary Tasmanians and ordinary Australians.

Finally, the authors of the letter make some suggestions as to what needs to happen to help people living in the bush. Foremost amongst these suggestions is education, corresponding exactly with the views of the Australian Labor Party and our policies as outlined by the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, in a recent speech. I was very pleased about that. I will let these `Disillusioned Voters' know that at least they have one party that will look after them. There is one party that is in tune with the thinking of country people, with regional people. It is a party that is letting Tasmania out of the shadow of six years of Liberal mismanagement. It is the party that has just been returned in New South Wales. It is the Australian Labor Party.

The Australian Labor Party is the only party that is going to give regional and country Australia the sort of direction they need for the future. We will need to look at that in a whole range of areas. Some figures have come out today regarding how Telstra has been cut to pieces in Tasmania. The minister got up today to answer a question and made a bit of a song and dance about it. The government has cut enormous amounts out of Telstra's budget in Tasmania. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It has been quite a day today for members to focus on the issues of rural and regional Australia. This debate gives me a great opportunity to highlight the direct effect of the rural doctor shortage in the electorate of Pearce, and I know it is more widespread than that. In the rural part of my electorate, in particular, some difficulties have arisen in regard to the retention of foreign doctors who have been prepared to locate in rural areas of Australia.

speech.para: The difficulty of attracting a doctor to the country town of Beverley in my electorate over several years was the catalyst for the Shire of Beverley to take some very innovative approaches to the problem. Two years ago the shire decided to actually employ a doctor for the town of Beverley and the surrounding region. Their search did locate a doctor from overseas who was subsequently employed and who served the community very well over that time. But recently, along with other country doctors who came from overseas, Beverley's doctor was under threat of deportation unless he was able to meet certain conditions, which I will refer to a little later.

The town were understandably upset, and I received a call from the shire president, Fred Bremner, who sought my assistance to ensure their doctor, Dr Gogna, was able to remain providing medical services to that community. With the support of residents—and I must say this is democracy as it ought to work—they sent me over 500 letters of support for Dr Gogna, and I was able to work with the appropriate state and federal ministers to ensure that this doctor and other Western Australian doctors were able to obtain the necessary extensions to continue practising and serving the rural and regional areas of Western Australia. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the ministers—the state minister for health, the federal Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, and also the federal Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Phillip Ruddock, who was especially helpful in providing a quick response to the situation the people of Beverley found themselves in.

The government has taken some very important steps to address the serious shortage of doctors in rural and remote areas with the Rural Incentive program. This program has, I believe, assisted over 400 GPs to relocate to rural areas. This is backed up by a very strong program to train country students by establishing departments of rural health in strategic locations around Australia. Indeed, in Western Australia, this will take place in the rural town of Geraldton, which is north of my electorate.

The value of this initiative, according to a discussion paper that was released by the Australian Medical Association—and it was a particularly good discussion paper entitled `Increasing rural medical services'—is that young people raised in rural and remote areas are twice as likely to return to their communities, so encouraging rural high school students to enter medical school is a very important long-term strategy for our communities. In Western Australia this scheme has the support of the University of Western Australia.

These, along with other initiatives, are important in the medium and the long term to improve the delivery of health care in rural and remote areas. However, there is currently a shortage of general practitioners, particularly in rural and remote areas of Western Australia, and we need to ensure a more streamlined system of attracting and retaining suitably qualified overseas doctors as a short-term interim measure before these other measures really begin to alleviate some of the problems.

The situation the people of Beverley found themselves in was distressing and unsettling and, from their perspective, unnecessary because Dr Gogna was an extremely well credentialled doctor. He had served the community of Beverley for two years. Indeed, his level of skill, ability and training was such that he was examining the final year medical students coming out of the University of WA. In order for him to remain under the current system, he was required to complete the Australian Medical Council examination. I think it is important we ensure that doctors coming into Australia from overseas are properly credentialled. We certainly need to ensure that rural people have only the best of services and, therefore, it is important that governments, both state and federal, ensure the proper qualification of those doctors coming into Australia to practise.

In the West Australian last Thursday, I noticed an article with the headline `Country pain over doctor bans' which had some quotes by the Vice-Chancellor of Murdoch University, Steven Schwartz. The article stated:
The Federal Government and the doctors' group—
in concert—
should remove barriers to the registration of foreign-trained doctors whose training met Australian standards . . .
He said specialists who had trained at some of the world's most prestigious medical schools had been denied entry into some Australian colleges.
In a paper published in the latest Policy journal, Professor Schwartz said foreign-trained doctors were restricted on the ground that they were not as well trained as Australians.

Professor Schwartz said that this may apply to doctors trained in some inferior universities. He also believes that health care should be opened up to market forces and that the restriction of doctor numbers has failed to curb spending, but it has resulted in poorer access to care. I guess that is particularly so for people in rural and remote areas. Professor Schwartz said these qualifications should be recognised where the qualifications are sound and meet our own standards. But he also said that access to the Medical Council examination, which was a requirement for permanent residency and vocational registration, should be more readily available to the doctors, and I wholeheartedly agree with that comment.

Rural communities have faced considerable hardships over the last decade or so. They have taken more than their fair share of pain, economically and socially, and I think we need to do everything we can for them. We need to do this in a cooperative manner, recognising that it is not only the federal government that can act on this; it is something that needs to be done in concert with the state governments and the peak representative bodies of the medical profession in Australia.

But we do need to do everything we can to remove the levels of anxiety felt by people in rural and remote areas. There is a good reason for that anxiety because, in the report done by the AMA and using Australian Bureau of Statistics and other information, they highlighted the fact that Australian death rates for all causes amongst people living in rural and remote zones were higher than those in metropolitan areas. There were some disturbing figures that came out from the ABS, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and other agencies in respect of that, which are incorporated in this report. We need to address that situation and ensure that country people do have proper access to appropriate medical services in their areas.

The short-term solutions require, as I said, the cooperation of state and federal governments and those peak representative bodies. Without that kind of cooperation we cannot resolve what is an immensely difficult issue. Everybody talks about the difficulties of resolving this issue. There are many factors that have given rise to the shortages of doctors in country towns. There is no one factor that has created this, but a number. Again, the report by the AMA highlights some of those difficulties confronted by rural and remote doctors. They include the high on-call burden; there is very little relief for doctors practising in country towns. There is difficulty sometimes in gaining access to local hospitals. There is professional isolation. There is the family's educational needs, which sometimes they have difficulty in meeting. There are a number of problems.

As I said, we need to resolve this problem cooperatively. I am certainly committed to working with the relevant ministers, both state and federal, the peak organisations and my colleagues in this place to find a way of ensuring appropriate medical services are available to rural and remote communities.

talk.start.para: —I take the opportunity of this debate to talk for just a few moments about the death of a man whom I believe this parliament and, indeed, the whole world should be honouring. Last Saturday, on his 53rd birthday, Doctor Michael Aris died of cancer in London, leaving grieving his wife, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, his two sons, Alexander and Kim, and a very large number of people around the world who had the most intense admiration, respect and affection for him.

speech.para: I was privileged to be one of those who knew him personally. We had discussions on a number of occasions, both when I was foreign minister and subsequently, about the appalling situation in Burma and what the international community might possibly be able to do to advance it.

Just a couple of days before his death I wrote and posted a letter to him saying how terribly distressed I was to hear of his terminal illness and how disgusted I was at the news, which had, by then, echoed around the world, of the appalling cruelty of the Burmese authorities in denying him entry to Burma to pay a last visit to his wife. I said to him in that letter that I hoped he had some sense of the enormous respect and affection there was for him personally all around the world not only from those who had the privilege of knowing him personally but also from those many more who had to be content with admiring him at a distance.

I also said to him that few people can possibly imagine the stress which that enforced separation must have had on his personal and family life, compounded throughout as it was by the impossibility of knowing when it would ever end, but that his bravery and his decency had been obvious to everyone. Unhappily, and very sadly, he could never have received that letter, but I do think it is appropriate to put on the public record a few of the sentiments in it and to spell out in just a little more detail the nature of that bravery and that decency.

Michael Aris was a man of great personal charm and warmth, with a calm and a gentleness about him characteristic, perhaps, of what one might expect of a scholar in the Tibetan language and literature; a calmness and a gentleness, however, that rather belied an immense inner strength. And make no mistake about that strength: he needed absolutely immense reserves of it to cope with the stress of the last decade. He was deeply and utterly devoted to Aung San Suu Kyi, his wife of 27 years, and one can barely imagine the pain that was involved in that separation and the responsibility that he had to keep his young family together, without the boys' mother, throughout that more than a decade.

The obvious stress began in 1988 when Suu Kyi went to Burma to care for her dying mother—the widow, of course, of her father, the great national hero, Aung San—and then stayed on to lead the democracy movement in response to those tumultuous events of 1988; the hopes and the fears that were running throughout the community in response also to the horrors of the regime's attempted suppression of the democracy movement. Michael Aris identifies in the preface to his book the circumstances of that 1988 decision. He said:
Suu picked up the phone to learn that her mother had suffered a severe stroke. She put the phone down and at once started to pack. I had a premonition that our lives would change for ever.
That is in the preface to the book Freedom from Fear and Other Writings that Michael Aris edited, putting together the work of Suu Kyi for an international audience.

The most appalling separation was at the end, of course, but it was preceded by many long years of acute and enormous difficulty. He and the boys were completely denied access to her from 1989 to 1992—the years of house arrest and, indeed, total isolation—when, for two years and four months, the family went by without even a letter passing between them. Some visits were allowed in the period from 1992 to 1995 but, since January 1996, again there has been no physical contact at all.

The most appalling separation of all must have been in those last few weeks and days when both of them, Michael and Suu Kyi, must have known they would never see each other again—knowing that, if she left the country to see him in London, she would never be allowed back because forcing her into exile has been the absolute centrepiece of the Burmese regime's whole strategy for the last few years. It is nonsense, I believe, to suggest that the regime should and could have been taken at its word when it said that she would be allowed back. If it had been genuine, it would have opened up the option for him to come to Burma. It just refused to do that with utterly spurious arguments about the quality of available medical treatment, and the whole thing was a cynical and ugly exercise.

But both of them bore this final separation with great dignity as they had borne all the others because they knew that what they were fighting for—Aung San Suu Kyi herself on the ground in Burma and Michael Aris as her voice and her presence throughout the rest of the world—was the life, the happiness and the future of millions of people and they were both prepared to devote their lives to that cause. Michael Aris made it clear, again in the preface to his edited book, that he understood the nature of the commitment he might one day be ultimately obliged to make. He knew that this day, this time, this obligation and this sacrifice would probably come. He said:
She constantly reminded me—
in the days before their marriage—
that one day she would have to return to Burma, that she counted on my support at that time, not as her due, but as a favour.
Again, he says rather movingly:

Sometimes I am beset by fears that circumstances and national considerations might tear us apart just when we are so happy in each other that separation would be a torment. And yet such fears are so futile and inconsequential: if we love and cherish each other as much as we can while we can, I am sure love and compassion will triumph in the end.

This is what he was writing in the early 1970s in anticipation of what might come to pass, and it did come to pass and it has been horrifying. I did not think I would ever find myself quoting John Pilger with any degree of approval, but he did write a piece in the press this morning which I think captures exactly what I want to say about Michael Aris:

Just as Aung San Suu Kyi is Burma's most famous heroine, her husband, Michael Aris, was one of its heroes. Michael, who died at the weekend, was not simply the Oxford professor who supported his extraordinary wife; he gave his life to the cause of freedom in that suffering country.

Might I say just finally in the few moments remaining that this is a time, this week, with this unhappy death behind us, for the international community and for this government and parliament to renew our commitment once more to achieving peace and democracy in Burma. The need is stronger than ever. The country is in absolute terrible limbo— economically, politically, in terms of human rights, in terms of the primacy of the drug trade and in every other way—and it desperately needs to break out of that cycle.

No-one suggests that the task is an easy one. The leverage of the rest of the world is very limited. The lever of ASEAN membership, the main game for so long in terms of putting pressure to bear on Burma to behave better, has been lost with the admission of Burma to ASEAN in mid-1997. China, one of the other countries with real leverage, has obviously never been interested in any kind of political reform. Japan is interested and it does have real influence but, unfortunately, it is engaged in a rather misconceived policy of constructive engagement which has meant that its potential to really be influential in changing the course of action through the application of its aid policy has not been exercised at all. Japan has not been nearly as influential a force for good as it may have been.

There is some small ray of hope with the package that has just been put together by the UN and the World Bank, presented last October by Special Envoy Alvaro de Soto to the Burmese authorities, in which it is proposed that political progress be rewarded with $1 billion in financial and humanitarian aid. That will involve some flexibility on both sides if a process of that kind can be put in place.

I just want to conclude by saying that suggestions that are emerging in some quarters—for a long time in ASEAN, now in the US Congress more visibly and, I fear, in some quarters in the Australian government—that Suu Kyi's time personally has come and gone, that she is too intransigent, too inflexible, cannot lead the way forward and should no longer be regarded as the centrepiece of the democratic movement struggle, I believe, should be absolutely rejected. That diminishes her judgment and her intelligence which, I believe, have always been of a kind—and it is partly based on my conversations with her husband—that would lead her to be appropriately flexible whenever there was half a chance of that being reciprocated. To challenge her authority or question it in this way is not only to diminish her and her magnifi cent stature but also to diminish the memory of Michael Aris which it is totally appropriate that the world and this parliament, as I say, should be honouring this week.

talk.start.para: —I would like an opportunity to place the needs of the horticultural industries in my electorate before the parliament. We have had another fruit fly outbreak in Sunraysia which impacts very substantially on a number of commodities—grapes, stone fruit, et cetera—but I do want to particularly speak this afternoon about the citrus industry.

speech.para: In the last two years, this industry has experienced a remarkable recovery by the sheer hard work of the growers and their marketing organisations. This turnaround has been greatly assisted by access to lucrative US markets in the off season over there in the Northern Hemisphere. For years, access has been prevented to this market owing to the problem of fruit fly infestation in the growing areas of the arid zones across the middle of Australia. Better monitoring and other government sponsored initiatives have overcome some of these problems and growers in the last two seasons have enjoyed better prospects. It is, therefore, of some concern to report on a fruit fly outbreak in Sunraysia.

This is a major setback for my growers. The impacts on international and interstate market access will produce major economic downsides for growers, which is the last thing they need when the industry, particularly the citrus industry, is just starting to recover from years of decline. The Sunraysia district of Victoria and New South Wales is one of three major inland arid zone districts in Australia. Other regions include the Riverland in South Australia, in the electorate of the member for Wakefield and Speaker of the House, and the Riverina region, catered for by the member for Riverina.

The fruit fly initiatives put in place some years ago were a giant step in interstate cooperation. It is quite a model for finding a way through those difficulties of federation—including the rail gauge problem, which I know you, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, often refer to—where phytosanitary food standards and so forth are controlled by states. And here we have major economic zones across three states in the centre of Australia.

The whole region now is a huge fruit fly quarantine area across a major area of inland Australia, as I said, including the electorates of Murray and Farrer as well as those others I have mentioned. With coordinated monitoring and mobile fruit fly stops on major highways this huge area can provide international fruit fly freedom status by providing phytosanitary certification to satisfy our international obligations. It is this that has opened up opportunities, particularly for the citrus industry—there is a lot more to be done—and they have reaped the benefits in the last two years. It was a struggle, but I am immensely proud of their efforts. So it is a major setback, considering the huge amount of work that has been undertaken involving special tri-state agreements between South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria.

Incidences of fruit fly occur from time to time. Some are minor and some substantial—thankfully, we have not had a substantial one for some time—and the impacts vary. The current discovery of flies was on a property in Cardross, not far from my birthplace in Sunraysia on the Victorian side of the river. It is understood to be a minor outbreak, with three male flies and some larvae discovered. The Victorian Department of Natural Resources and Environment has standard procedures, which were implemented immediately because we have obligations under our international trading agreements to report the discovery of fruit fly, no matter how minor. The impact is the implementation of a 15 kilometre suspension zone around the discovery centre for a 12-month period. This requires any fruit from that region to be treated in a very expensive way, therefore reducing the return to growers.

There are some very sensitive fruit fly markets—the US is one of them and Korea is another—where market access has not yet been able to be achieved. Fruit fly is the major sticking point for the Koreans to agree to let off-season Australian oranges into their markets. Other Asian markets and New Zealand cause an additional problem in that they require an 80 kilometre radius around the centre of the discovery site, and that virtually precludes the whole of the Sunraysia region from fruit fly freedom status. Growers will incur additional costs in having their fruit treated in order to obtain confidence and access in some of those markets.

Only last week growers were greatly confident about opportunities in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh as well as Taiwan—and I have mentioned Korea, an elusive market but one which is getting closer. In fact, a delegation of Australian citrus growers is to visit some of those countries in April, May and June of this year. So this latest incident could not have happened at a worse time.

I have said that I am very proud of the Australian growers of citrus in my electorate. It was not that long ago that they were outside the parliament protesting at that time about their very poor financial position owing to intense international competition, especially due to the import of concentrated so-called juice from Brazil which saw some major readjustment of the whole industry, particularly in regard to summer valencias, which was the juice fruit. The industry has fought back and, with the assistance of the Commonwealth contribution of $595,000 to a tri-state fruit fly strategy and another $1.5 million of citrus market diversification grant funds, it has made a major impact on fruit fly—including, of all things, the sterilisation of male flies, mobile fruit blocks and a research, surveillance and monitoring program right through the growing region.

There were two outbreaks of fruit fly in the 1996-97 season and one in 1997-98, and we were rather hoping not to have any discoveries in the current season. But with all of that commitment of funding and with all of those initiatives—mobile fruit blocks and even sanctions on visitors who visit the region who are required to remove any fruit from their baggage and from their motor vehicles and dispose of it under sufferance of penalty—we still have fruit fly discovered in our zone, and it is a bitter disappointment.

I want to make a plea to all members present who might be prepared to advise their own constituency. In Sunraysia we welcome tourists and we welcome backpackers, who bring their disposable income and dispose of it in the wonderful Murray Valley region. But we do not want them to bring fruit which has the risk of being infested with fruit fly. The two flies discovered in Cardross came from somewhere, and not far from where they were discovered some larvae were found in a pear tree, which was basically a backyard tree with no maintenance for pest infestation.

So we have two problems. One is community awareness. Despite signs, despite a considerable amount of advertising on television, visitors still bypass and come via a non-main highway route and bring fruit into the region which has the risk of bringing in fruit fly. The downside economic impacts for our $100 million industry are quite substantial when you are talking about the restriction that a fruit fly discovery can place on their international market access—and, indeed, on their interstate access. It is interesting that a major source of fruit fly is the western regions around outer-suburban Sydney and that any access for Sunraysia fruit all the way back to Sydney requires cold storage de-infestation and extra expense to growers. It has been said that that zone was the source of some of the fruit fly discoveries in the past.

The second thing we can do is to have a local awareness program. There are many hobby trees and backyard trees—peaches, plums and even apples and pears—in backyards that do not have the maintenance that a professional orchard has, and I believe that there ought to be some sanction or even some encouragement and carrots to perhaps encourage people to grub out those trees if they cannot maintain them to a proper professional standard. Or there could be some concession given on their rents, or local government by-laws could be used to encourage the whole community to take part. The economic downsides in Sunraysia that affect growers will affect the whole community, and they need to be involved. (Time expired)
